s.text: It symbolized American energy," writes Rudi Stern in his 1988 book, The New Let There Be Neon . A neon sign in the window also advertised the fact that a merchant was flush enough to have spent some coin.

But who window shops anymore, except at 35 mph, through a window set in the frame of a vehicle?

You couldn't say the same of a CLOSED sign--if it was off, would that mean proprietors lurking in the back waiting to make a sale?
In the medium's heyday, the 1940s, the United States boasted more than 2,000 neon shops.
The market blossomed in the late 1980s, with the rise of wholesale buyer's clubs like Costco and SAM'S Club.
